text:
The "Retrieve All Images..." option on HTTP Requests is does not mimic the
functionality provided by a browser cache (all images are loaded for every
request rather than just the first time they are hit).

Oliver Rossmueller suggested the creation of a new test element similar to
cookie/header/auth handling that does image caching per thread.

In the mean time the work around is to manually request the images in their own
HTTP Request test elements.

text:
This isn't clear to me. The HTTP Sampler only downloads duplicated images once per request, 
so that - at the request level - the Sampler does mimic the functionality provided by a browser 
cache. 
 
Are you saying that the downloaded images should be cached at the thread level, so that the 
thread grouping would function as a browser session (actually this does seem to make sense 
to me) ? Or would we need to introduce a new element that would function as a users' browser 
session ? 
 
How exactly do you see the session/thread grouping working ?

creator: seade@apache.org
text:
I am a little rusty as to the exact symptoms of the problem, but the essesence
was that I would expect the "Retrieve All Images..." functionality to pull down
images in the same fashion as the caching mechanism of a regular browser - i.e.
each thread (perhaps even each cycle) should pull down all referenced images
once and only once (since further requests would come from the cache if a
browser was hitting the site).  If I recall correctly only a subset of the
images were being downloaded and this seemed to occur for every request.

I am a bit confused by this bug submission. The way netscape 3-6 and IE work is 
the browser caches all images by the URL. The only time a browser retrieves the 
same images on subsequent pages is if the browser is set to download all images 
all the time. The way the samplers work, it will always retrieve all images 
once, since the images are added to a list. Duplicate images are not added. the 
images are then retrieved by the sampler. The sampler does not immitate a 
browser strictly, since a browser will launch multiple threads to get the 
images at the same time. This is specified in W3C's HTTP specification. HTTP1.0 
limits the number of concurrent connections to the same server to 4 and HTTP1.1 
limits it to 2 concurrent connections to the same server. If we really want to 
immitate browser behavior, you can achieve this without writing a new 
controller to cache the images. Simply make a separate thread group that gets 
the images. You should be able to figure this out by looking at the number of 
hits per page and comparing to the number of times each image is downloaded.
creator: woolfel@yahoo.com

text:
Yes, I understand the intent of this bug is to request a new configuration
element (in the lines of the cookie handler) that keeps track of which images
have already been downloaded by a particular client and prevents repeated downloads.

It makes a lot of sense, and I'm ready to work on this -- but only once we
undertake the migration to Apache Jakarta Commons HTTPClient.
